Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Cathodoluminescence Spectrometer on an Electron Probe Microanalyzer for Multidisciplinary Research and Hands-On Education at Fayetteville State University
Award.AbstractNarration:
This instrumentation project, proposed by Fayetteville State University (FSU) through the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) program is to acquire a cathodoluminescence spectrometer that will be installed on a state-of-the-art field-emission Electron Probe Microanalyzer at a multi-user facility at FSU. It will be open for access and support research at academic and federal agencies in North Carolina, South Carolina and nationwide. The new instrument will be used for materials characterization, which will significantly strengthen the research capabilities at the FSU. The new instrument will be used as a centerpiece for training minority students at FSU, producing more minority and female professionals for diversified and motivated STEM workforces. In addition, the new capability will serve as an open platform for outreach to local communities.

This MRI project supports several research projects at Fayetteville State University as the fast X-ray detection using nanoscale size and composition-controllable scintillator nanowires, effects of dimensionality, size and chemical doping on luminescence of ceria nanofibers, fundamental mechanisms controlling growth and packing factor of nanocrystals in ion implantation, and magmatic and tectonic processes by analyzing zoning in igneous and detrital zircons. Through these in situ studies, the material microstructure, shape, size, composition and luminescence properties can be correlated from the same specimens.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cathodoluminescence (CL) is a light emission phenomenon from certain luminescent materials upon excitation by high-energy electrons. This project through NSF Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) Program supported to acquire two CL spectrometers installed on a state-of-the-art field-emission Electron Probe Microanalyzer (EPMA) at a multi-user facility at Fayetteville State University (FSU). On September 28, 2018, two related CL detectors were installed on the EPMA instrument by JEOL: (1) xCLent IV Advanced B Hyperspectral Cathodoluminescence Detector, which is a is a fully integrated CL system for both hyperspectral mapping and spectroscopy in the range of 200 - 950 nm; and (2) Panchromatic Cathodoluminescence (PCL) Detector, which is used for imaging only using wavelengths in the range of 200 - 900 nm, and such imaging can be conducted simultaneously with other detectors such as secondary electron detector, backscattered electron detector, X-ray energy-dispersive spectrometer and up to five wavelength-dispersive spectrometers.

The new instruments significantly strengthened the research capabilities in materials characterization at the FSU, supporting the research on fast X-ray detection using nanoscale scintillator nanowires, effects of dimensionality, size and chemical doping on luminescence of ceria and perovskite nanofibers, mechanisms controlling growth and packing factor of nanocrystals in ion implantation, and magmatic and tectonic processes by analyzing zoning. Through these studies, the material microstructure, shape, size, composition and luminescence properties can be correlated.

The new instruments were used as one of the centerpieces for training minority students at FSU. The students received training in labs and research projects. Five undergraduates from FSU and one high-school student from a local high school in Fayetteville were involved in 5 publications using the new instruments.

The new instruments are open for access to FSU users, providing professional development opportunities to FSU faculty and staff members. They are also open to external users, including users from Appalachian State University, College of Charleston, East Carolina University, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, University of North Carolina at Wilmington, University of South Carolina, and local industries.
